articles.headline: Liberia, Ravaged by Ebola, Faces a Future Without It
articles.snippet: The West African nation, which is improving its health care systems, now has Ebola under control after being overwhelmed by the disease last year.
articles.abstract: The West African nation, which is improving its health care systems, now has Ebola under control after being overwhelmed by the disease last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — When a taxi dropped off a man dying of Ebola one evening in June 2014, the Logan Town clinic was defenseless.

articles.headline: Unless You Are Spock, Irrelevant Things Matter in Economic Behavior
articles.snippet: People are not as rational as economists would like to believe, but there are ways to nudge people into doing what’s best for them.
articles.abstract: People are not as rational as economists would like to believe, but there are ways to nudge people into doing what’s best for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in my teaching career I managed to get most of the students in my class mad at me. A midterm exam caused the problem.

articles.headline: Credit Cards With 2% Rebates, While (or if) They Last
articles.snippet: These cards are popular with reward seekers, but making them profitable for issuers has been difficult. Now four companies are trying them again.
articles.abstract: These cards are popular with reward seekers, but making them profitable for issuers has been difficult. Now four companies are trying them again.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the holy grail for many seekers of credit card rewards has been a guaranteed 2 percent back on every dollar they spend.

articles.headline: New Math for Retirees and the 4% Withdrawal Rule
articles.snippet: Though the concept has been celebrated and criticized, it has come under scrutiny again, particularly as people are now retiring during a period of low interest rates.
articles.abstract: Though the concept has been celebrated and criticized, it has come under scrutiny again, particularly as people are now retiring during a period of low interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than two decades ago, Bill Bengen, then a financial planner in Southern California, said he had several anxious clients with the same question: How much can I spend in retirement without running out of money?

articles.headline: Accused of Spying for China, Until She Wasn’t
articles.snippet: A National Weather Service flood forecaster in Ohio faced federal economic espionage charges, until her case was dropped as abruptly as it had upended her life.
articles.abstract: A National Weather Service flood forecaster in Ohio faced federal economic espionage charges, until her case was dropped as abruptly as it had upended her life.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Monday, Oct. 20, 2014, Sherry Chen drove, as usual, to her office at the National Weather Service in Wilmington, Ohio, where she forecast flood threats along the Ohio River. She was a bit jet-lagged, having returned a few days earlier from a visit to China. But as she headed to her desk, she says, she had no reason to think it was anything other than an ordinary day. Then her boss summoned her.

articles.headline: Billionaire Lifts Marco Rubio, Politically and Personally
articles.snippet: As Marco Rubio has ascended in the ranks of Republican politics, an auto dealer named Norman Braman has emerged as a remarkable and unusual patron.
articles.abstract: As Marco Rubio has ascended in the ranks of Republican politics, an auto dealer named Norman Braman has emerged as a remarkable and unusual patron.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — One day in the State Capitol in Tallahassee, Marco Rubio, the young speaker of the House, strayed from the legislative proceedings to single out a lanky, silver-haired man seated in the balcony: a billionaire auto dealer named Norman Braman.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Steve Eder

articles.headline: An App That Helps Drivers Earn the Most From Their Trips
articles.snippet: A free analytics site allows drivers to use their daily income, number of fares, working hours, expenses and mileage to calculate pay and determine profitable driving patterns.
articles.abstract: A free analytics site allows drivers to use their daily income, number of fares, working hours, expenses and mileage to calculate pay and determine profitable driving patterns.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Steve Smith began driving for Uber and Lyft several months ago, he concentrated on picking up passengers near his Walnut Creek neighborhood in the San Francisco Bay Area.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Liberia Conquers Ebola, but Faces a Crisis of Faith
articles.snippet: Churches have been holding special prayers, revivals and workshops, with the purpose of refastening ties frayed by Ebola, a disease that made many fear those closest to them.
articles.abstract: Churches have been holding special prayers, revivals and workshops, with the purpose of refastening ties frayed by Ebola, a disease that made many fear those closest to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — It decimated hospitals, schools, families, fortunes and, for many, even their faith.

articles.headline: Campus Debates on Israel Drive a Wedge Between Jews and Minorities
articles.snippet: Student groups nationwide are proposing that their colleges divest from companies that do business with Israel, a sign that a campaign is gaining traction.
articles.abstract: Student groups nationwide are proposing that their colleges divest from companies that do business with Israel, a sign that a campaign is gaining traction.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The debates can stretch from dusk to dawn, punctuated by tearful speeches and forceful shouting matches, with accusations of racism, colonialism and anti-Semitism. At dozens of college campuses across the country, student government councils are embracing resolutions calling on their administrations to divest from companies that enable what they see as Israel’s mistreatment of Palestinians.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Tamar Lewin

articles.headline: Networks Fret as Ad Dollars Flow to Digital Media
articles.snippet: Traditional television, once seen as the best way to reach a broad audience, is splintering with the rise of digital services like Netflix, YouTube, Snapchat and Vine.
articles.abstract: Traditional television, once seen as the best way to reach a broad audience, is splintering with the rise of digital services like Netflix, YouTube, Snapchat and Vine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beginning Monday, television networks will roll out the red carpet for marketers during the annual bazaar known as the upfronts, trying to lure them into committing tens of billions of ad dollars for the coming TV season. If things go well, the networks will sell as much as 75 percent of their advertising time in the negotiations that follow a week of flashy presentations and star-studded parties.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Uber Funding Talks Highlight the Speedy Pace of Investments
articles.snippet: Uber, Yik Yak and others have raised more money in less time, driven by money flowing in from hedge funds, strategic investors and more.
articles.abstract: Uber, Yik Yak and others have raised more money in less time, driven by money flowing in from hedge funds, strategic investors and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber raised a total of more than $2 billion from investors in June and December last year — and is now back for another round. The anonymous messaging start-up Yik Yak collected $73.5 million in three financing rounds in seven months, and Zenefits, a human resources start-up, raised more than $580 million in less than two years, with the latest deal done last week.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: I.M.F. and Central Bank Loom Large Over Greece’s Debt Talks
articles.snippet: Each institution is a creditor to Greece that expects it to repay billions of dollars of debt in the coming weeks.
articles.abstract: Each institution is a creditor to Greece that expects it to repay billions of dollars of debt in the coming weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greek leaders have fought fiercely in recent months with politicians from other European countries over relief on Greece’s vast debt load.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis, Jack Ewing and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Says King Won’t Attend Meetings in U.S.
articles.snippet: The decision appeared to be a signal of Saudi Arabia’s continued displeasure with the Obama administration over United States relations with Iran, its rising regional adversary.
articles.abstract: The decision appeared to be a signal of Saudi Arabia’s continued displeasure with the Obama administration over United States relations with Iran, its rising regional adversary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia announced on Sunday that its new monarch, King Salman, would not be attending meetings at the White House with President Obama or a summit gathering at Camp David this week, in an apparent signal of its continued displeasure with the administration over United States relations with Iran, its rising regional adversary.

articles.headline: How Is U.S. TV Changing? Ask Jane
articles.snippet: The show “Jane the Virgin” demonstrated the power of shows that appealed to Hispanics as well as broader audiences, and networks are preparing to introduce more of them.
articles.abstract: The show “Jane the Virgin” demonstrated the power of shows that appealed to Hispanics as well as broader audiences, and networks are preparing to introduce more of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gina Rodriguez was home in Chicago last month when she stopped at a Subway sandwich shop on the way to the golf course with her father. The Hispanic teenager working behind the counter instantly recognized her as the star of the CW Network’s breakout comedy-drama “Jane the Virgin” and said that the order was on the house. Ms. Rodriguez protested, but the girl insisted, telling the actress how inspirational it was to see someone on television who looked like her and grew up in her neighborhood.

articles.headline: @_FloridaMan Beguiles With the Hapless and Harebrained
articles.snippet: A beguilingly anonymous Twitter author with the mug shot of an Indiana man unspools, tweet by tweet, a composite of Florida’s nuttiness.
articles.abstract: A beguilingly anonymous Twitter author with the mug shot of an Indiana man unspools, tweet by tweet, a composite of Florida’s nuttiness.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Dangling into the sea like America’s last-ditch lifeline, the state of Florida beckons. Hustlers and fugitives, million-dollar hucksters and harebrained thieves, Armani-wearing drug traffickers and hapless dope dealers all congregate, scheme and revel in the Sunshine State. It’s easy to get in, get out or get lost.

articles.headline: Tony Rodham’s Ties Invite Scrutiny for Hillary and Bill Clinton
articles.snippet: As he has cycled through various ventures, Mr. Rodham has leveraged his connections to his sister and brother-in-law.
articles.abstract: As he has cycled through various ventures, Mr. Rodham has leveraged his connections to his sister and brother-in-law.
articles.lead_paragraph: The heavyset 60-year-old man who walked with a cane seemed an unlikely speaker at the glamorous launch party for a cosmetics company held in Santa Monica, Calif., in March.

articles.headline: King Salman Upends Status Quo in Region and the Royal Family
articles.snippet: King Salman has rattled alliances with the United States and regional powers that for decades have been the bedrock of stability for his kingdom, and he has also shaken up the Saudi royal family.
articles.abstract: King Salman has rattled alliances with the United States and regional powers that for decades have been the bedrock of stability for his kingdom, and he has also shaken up the Saudi royal family.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — For much of the past decade, change has come slowly to Saudi Arabia, if at all.

articles.headline: ‘American Idol’ Will End Its Run in 2016
articles.snippet: Fox’s singing competition, which made its debut in 2002, was one of the most popular reality shows but has lost its luster.
articles.abstract: Fox’s singing competition, which made its debut in 2002, was one of the most popular reality shows but has lost its luster.
articles.lead_paragraph: At its height, “American Idol” minted breakout stars and drew more than 30 million viewers an episode. It was the No. 1 broadcast show for eight years, provided a boon to an ailing music industry and was the sort of appointment television that industry executives are desperately trying to recreate.

articles.headline: Greece Moves to Pay Debt, but European Finance Ministers Unsatisfied
articles.snippet: Athens authorized a payment to the International Monetary Fund as eurozone officials noted “open issues.”
articles.abstract: Athens authorized a payment to the International Monetary Fund as eurozone officials noted “open issues.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The government of Greece, quickly running out of cash, moved on Monday to quell fears of an imminent default on its debts, authorizing its treasury to make a big loan payment to the International Monetary Fund.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and James Kanter
